The mood in Austria ’ s industry continued to decline faster than in the eurozone in August .
The Purchasing Manager Index ( PMI ) was at 46.7 points at a 37-month low .
Despite this , Austria has the third best sentiment behind Ireland and the Netherlands , according to the Markit Institute on Monday for its survey of 3,000 companies .
Unlike in Austria , the PMI of the euro zone rose by 1.1 points to 45.1 points , which means that for the 13th consecutive month the index is below the 50 meter mark indicating growth .
The only industry in Ireland hit this threshold with 50.9 points in August .
Last was the Greeks ( 42.1 points ) .
In Germany , France , and Spain , the mood barometer fell more slowly than in previous months .
In Spain , the index reached the highest level since March , at 44.0 points .
The slightly weakened descent may well mean that the worst has survived ,  said Markit economist Rob Dobson .
But industry remains the number one brake on growth , at least in the third quarter .
There is no prospect of a rapid return to the growth zone : export orders in the eurozone have fallen as fast as they have since November 2011 .
The companies therefore cut jobs for the seventh consecutive month .
In China , too , industrial production fell more sharply in August than was initially thought .
The mood barometer fell from 49.3 points in the previous month to 47.6 points .
Experts had initially expected 47.8 points .
The Purchasing Manager Index bases its figures on representative surveys of 3,000 European industrial companies .
Amongst other things , developments in sales , employment , storage and prices are being highlighted .
